awd_titl_txt: Global and Local Properties of Discrete Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The theory of combinatorial structures is closely related to several areas of mathematics, including algebra, logic, number theory, and probability, as well as to other fields such as information theory, coding theory, theoretical computer science, and statistical physics. Investigating random and pseudo-random structures has become an important research topic, particularly because the results and the techniques developed proved to be useful in the study of large networks in important applications. A recently-discovered connection between sparse combinatorial structures and enumeration problems yielded several deep results that call for further study. This research project focuses on understanding the robustness of important properties of dense structures and testing whether they are inherited by random sparse substructures, with the goal of developing a unified theory. The project will involve training of graduate students through involvement in the research, and it is anticipated that some of the results will be integrated into courses for graduate student training.

A central focus of combinatorics over the past twenty years has been the introduction and proof of various random analogues of well-known theorems in extremal graph theory, Ramsey theory, and additive combinatorics. Recently, the so-called container method was developed, which proved to be useful to attack these questions and many others. One direction of research in this project will focus on applications of the method, and it is expected that this exploration will lead to new exciting questions and directions.  In particular, the following related areas are to be investigated: (1) extremal questions in sparse structures; (2) embedding in subgraphs of sparse random and pseudo-random graphs; (3) applications of flag algebras; and (4) problems in bootstrap percolation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the project the PI studied combinatorics and its relation to additive number theory, probability theory and theoretical computer science. While supported by the grant, over 40 research papers were written, addressing important questions from the proposal and further developing general theories. During this project the PI supervised graduate students, mentored postdocs, developed courses related to the research, and organized conferences.


Intellectual Merit:
Some of the key results are the following: 

 Container Method:

One of the recent important breakthrough in combinatorics is the invention of the container method. The PI with Samotij further developed the method to be applicable for hypergraphs with larger uniformity.

Additionally, the PI further developed the graph container method and proved several counting and probabilistic results on the Boolean Lattice. 

 Extremal Problems:

The PI proved stability results for the classical (graph) Turan Theorem.  

The PI determined for an infinite family of hypergraphs their Turan density. Applying hypergraph Turan theory, the PI solved two problems in discrete geometry involving triangles.

Using the method of flag algebras, the PI determined the extremal hypergraph of the tetrahedra in the measure of cosquare density. 

The PI with coauthors solved a particular hypergraph Turan problem, whose resolution helped to solve a well-known counting problem on k-SAT functions.  

Additive Combinatorics:

The PI with coauthors had the first improvement on the size of maximum Sidon sets, since 1941.

The PI constructed co-Sidon sets, which has applications in coding theory.  

Broader Impacts: 

The PI organized several AMS sectional meetings, two Summer Schools at UIUC, one on the absorption method and one on algebraic methods in combinatorics, an Early Career Conference in Combinatorics at UIUC.

The PI advised over 10 graduate students, mentored five postdocs and developed three graduate courses, incorporating into the courses several results of the projects. 

The PI gave several lectures about the findings of the projects, posted   his papers on arxiv and publicly posted his class notes. 

The PI is a volunteer moderator for the arxiv, which is the main public server of preprints in mathematics.
